title: Expats told to sell homes before June to avoid tax slug
text:
"When determining whether you are an excluded foreign resident, you will need to take into account whether you are a foreign resident at the time that the capital gains tax event occurs and whether you have been a foreign resident for a continuous period of greater than six years," he said.

"If you owned your current or former principal place of residence before May 9, 2017, and were to sell if before June 30, 2020, then you are entitled to receive the full benefit of the main residence exemption under the transitional rule announced."

Mr Evans said deceased estates were also affected.

Lengthy delays

"Whether the deceased or beneficiary is either a tax resident of Australia or a foreign resident will have a major bearing on whether or not the beneficiary or beneficiaries will be able to access the main residence exemption."

Tax expert Robyn Jacobson, a senior trainer at TaxBanter, said the extension was appropriate given the lengthy delays to the passage of the legislation.

She said there were new rules to deal with "life events" such as terminal illness, death and marriage, or relationship breakdowns.

"If at the time of the capital gains tax event, an individual has been a foreign resident for no more than six years, and a life event happens to them during this period of foreign residency, the exemption will not be denied."

Advertisement

Ms Jacobson said the bill still had the practical effect of a retrospective denial of the exemption as far back as the start of the capital gains tax arrangements in September 1985.

She has been warning of the plan's shortcomings since it was first announced.

"This is unfair on Australian expatriates who may not be entitled to recognise the period they lived in their homes as their main residence. The tax treatment will be based on the taxpayer’s residency status at the time they sell, not their use of the property or their residency status throughout the ownership period.

"The measures will require affected taxpayers to determine their cost base back to when they acquired it to correctly calculate the capital gain.

"Taxpayers are unlikely to have retained tax records for their home for the entire ownership period because the law allows people to disregard the capital gain on the sale of their homes, so the expectation is that that the capital gain would not be taxable."

Ms Jacobson said the rules relating to deceased estates and marriage breakdowns remained complex and unclear.

The Coalition will use the changes to try to convince Labor and Senate crossbenchers to support the legislation, since they had expressed serious concerns before the May election.
description: Redrafted changes to capital gains tax exemptions for expatriate Australians living overseas remain complicated and potentially unfair, tax experts say.
